body:
The most jarring example is Shem Tob's copy of the gospel of Matthew in Hebrew. What's bizarre is that it often agrees with *Luke* over Matthew when using the Q source. Interesting, because often the Lukan version is more primitive and Hebraic than the Matthean version. I don't just mean minor details either. For example, the part where the people ask John what to do in chapter 3 is not extant in canonical Matthew, but it *is* in Luke...and a shorter version is also found in Hebrew Matthew! My guess is that Q was originally written in Hebrew, and that Shem Tob's text made use of this or padded it out with translations of the parts of Mark that were incorporated. And Matthew and Luke both made use of some sort of Greek translation of this document. More evidence is that the Shem Tob version also has several agreements with the gospel of Thomas over the canonical gospels, which also utilized Q. As well as agreements with long lost manuscripts not available in his time, so these variants could not have been the results of tampering by Jewish scribes (which did happen, as it also did to the canonical version by Roman scribes).

Some of these old manuscripts also appear to be checked against older sources, including Q, and often the original Hebrew version too. Sinaiticus and Bezae in particular have several variants in the synoptic gospels and even Acts which come from older versions than are available to us today, and updates from source documents that were originally erroneously copied. Some manuscripts of the Old Latin and Old Syriac have similar variants.

The gospel of the Hebrews, too, looks like it made use of this document, or an extremely early version of Luke. I cannot say it *is* Q, as it's definitely edited and harmonized from the existing gospels, but in places it gives a more primitive reading. Such as the beginning: "And it was in the days of Herod king of Judea, during the priesthood of Caiapha, a man named John went..." which is shorter and noticeably more Hebraic than Luke 3:1, and also has an incorrect detail about Herod being king of Judea instead of Galilee (and it's very hard to imagine a redactor editing it to make it shorter and more incorrect).

It may be that the story of the woman caught in adultery is also part of Q, as its style is very Lukan and it appears in a number of early manuscripts in the gospel of Luke instead of John. Perhaps scribes noticed it was not included in any of the canonical gospels and were trying to find a good place to put it before abandoning Q and losing it.

My guess is that Q was originally written in Hebrew, and that Shem Tob's text made use of this or padded it out with translations of the parts of Mark that were incorporated. And Matthew and Luke both made use of some sort of Greek translation of this document. More evidence is that the Shem Tob version also has several agreements with the gospel of Thomas over the canonical gospels, which also utilized Q. As well as agreements with long lost manuscripts not available in his time, so these variants could not have been the results of tampering by Jewish scribes (which did happen, as it also did to the canonical version by Roman scribes).

Some of these old manuscripts also appear to be checked against older sources, including Q, and often the original Hebrew version too. Sinaiticus and Bezae in particular have several variants in the synoptic gospels and even Acts which come from older versions than are available to us today, and updates from source documents that were originally erroneously copied. Such as the beginning: "And it was in the days of Herod king of Judea, during the priesthood of Caiapha, a man named John went..." which is shorter and noticeably more Hebraic than Luke 3:1, and also has an incorrect detail about Herod being king of Judea instead of Galilee (and it's very hard to imagine a redactor editing it to make it shorter and more incorrect).

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

title: Shem Tob's Hebrew, Codex Sinaiticus, Codex Bezae, Old Latin and Old Syriac have an interesting link with Q

body:
> Bible scholars and publishers have a vested interest in undermining and dividing God's word into as many separate translations as they can. It gives authority to the scholar to interpret the true meaning for you, and it also empowers the publishers to make more money by copyrighting and selling multiple copies. Greed and power fuel this industry and profession.

That's why I try to avoid translations. Even though I can't really read the original languages, I can still find the definitions of the words and piece it together.

> God preserves his word for all generations: Psalm 12:6-7 "The words of the Lord are pure words: as silver tried in a furnace of earth, purified seven times. Thou shalt keep them, O Lord, thou shalt preserve them from this generation forever."

That is referring to God staying true to his word, keeping his promises. It is not addressing the issue of divine preservation, read Jeremiah chapters 7-11 if you want that. And I'd recommend using an interlinear too, because most translations of this section are doctrinally biased and often blatantly dishonest.

> With hundreds of years of attacks and deception, the majority doubt The Bible including Christians. Which books are cannon, which translation is accurate, which source texts are the best? All of these questions have been strategically inserted to undermine God's word and destroy our faith and trust in The Bible.

The bible was authorized in 382 AD by the catholic church, not God. Prior to that there were as many canons as there are denominations. Notice how New Testament writers often refer to the apocrypha and even extra-apocryphal books like Enoch, even though we don't accept them today. They were familiar with all kinds of books and alluded to the parts they agree with. They did the same with classical literature and philosophy of the day.

If your mission is to insist that the thing we call, "the bible" is perfect, you won't like what God has to say about it speaking through the prophets. And good luck reconciliating Jesus with "God" in the torah and much of the Old Testament.
body_html:
Bible scholars and publishers have a vested interest in undermining and dividing God's word into as many separate translations as they can. It gives authority to the scholar to interpret the true meaning for you, and it also empowers the publishers to make more money by copyrighting and selling multiple copies. Greed and power fuel this industry and profession.

That's why I try to avoid translations. Even though I can't really read the original languages, I can still find the definitions of the words and piece it together.

God preserves his word for all generations: Psalm 12:6-7 "The words of the Lord are pure words: as silver tried in a furnace of earth, purified seven times. Thou shalt keep them, O Lord, thou shalt preserve them from this generation forever."

That is referring to God staying true to his word, keeping his promises. It is not addressing the issue of divine preservation, read Jeremiah chapters 7-11 if you want that. And I'd recommend using an interlinear too, because most translations of this section are doctrinally biased and often blatantly dishonest.

With hundreds of years of attacks and deception, the majority doubt The Bible including Christians. Which books are cannon, which translation is accurate, which source texts are the best? All of these questions have been strategically inserted to undermine God's word and destroy our faith and trust in The Bible.

The bible was authorized in 382 AD by the catholic church, not God. Prior to that there were as many canons as there are denominations. Notice how New Testament writers often refer to the apocrypha and even extra-apocryphal books like Enoch, even though we don't accept them today. They were familiar with all kinds of books and alluded to the parts they agree with. They did the same with classical literature and philosophy of the day.

If your mission is to insist that the thing we call, "the bible" is perfect, you won't like what God has to say about it speaking through the prophets. And good luck reconciliating Jesus with "God" in the torah and much of the Old Testament.

post.body:
The most jarring example is Shem Tob's copy of the gospel of Matthew in Hebrew. What's bizarre is that it often agrees with *Luke* over Matthew when using the Q source. Interesting, because often the Lukan version is more primitive and Hebraic than the Matthean version. I don't just mean minor details either. For example, the part where the people ask John what to do in chapter 3 is not extant in canonical Matthew, but it *is* in Luke...and a shorter version is also found in Hebrew Matthew! My guess is that Q was originally written in Hebrew, and that Shem Tob's text made use of this or padded it out with translations of the parts of Mark that were incorporated. And Matthew and Luke both made use of some sort of Greek translation of this document. More evidence is that the Shem Tob version also has several agreements with the gospel of Thomas over the canonical gospels, which also utilized Q. As well as agreements with long lost manuscripts not available in his time, so these variants could not have been the results of tampering by Jewish scribes (which did happen, as it also did to the canonical version by Roman scribes).

Some of these old manuscripts also appear to be checked against older sources, including Q, and often the original Hebrew version too. Sinaiticus and Bezae in particular have several variants in the synoptic gospels and even Acts which come from older versions than are available to us today, and updates from source documents that were originally erroneously copied. Some manuscripts of the Old Latin and Old Syriac have similar variants.

The gospel of the Hebrews, too, looks like it made use of this document, or an extremely early version of Luke. I cannot say it *is* Q, as it's definitely edited and harmonized from the existing gospels, but in places it gives a more primitive reading. Such as the beginning: "And it was in the days of Herod king of Judea, during the priesthood of Caiapha, a man named John went..." which is shorter and noticeably more Hebraic than Luke 3:1, and also has an incorrect detail about Herod being king of Judea instead of Galilee (and it's very hard to imagine a redactor editing it to make it shorter and more incorrect).

It may be that the story of the woman caught in adultery is also part of Q, as its style is very Lukan and it appears in a number of early manuscripts in the gospel of Luke instead of John. Perhaps scribes noticed it was not included in any of the canonical gospels and were trying to find a good place to put it before abandoning Q and losing it.

Some of these old manuscripts also appear to be checked against older sources, including Q, and often the original Hebrew version too. Sinaiticus and Bezae in particular have several variants in the synoptic gospels and even Acts which come from older versions than are available to us today, and updates from source documents that were originally erroneously copied. body: You have absolutely no authority to claim that the bible is the word of God, much less a particular translation of it. And no, King James I and Steven Anderson aren't God.
body_html: You have absolutely no authority to claim that the bible is the word of God, much less a particular translation of it. And no, King James I and Steven Anderson aren't God.

body:
> On what authority do you claim The Bible isn't God's word? Telling me I have no authority is a nonsensical statement to make. Obviously we are both expressing our opinions and where we place our faith. My faith is in the King James as God's perfect word in English.

The burden of proof is on the accuser. I recall no such incident where God spoke to us and said a book was his word, much less a particular translation of it. In fact, I believe there is an incident in the old testament where God praises the Israelites for rejecting a prophet's message when it wasn't God speaking through him.

> Anderson is likely a Jesuit agent. If you aren't aware of controlled opposition, or can't entertain the idea that one person doesn't represent and entire group, then we have little to talk about. I'd like to create a guild on here where Christians founded in proper Bible Doctrine and aware of "conspiracies" can have meaningful conversation and exchanges. You and I won't make any progress.

I only used him as an example because he's the only major KJV-onlyist I can think of. I know of organizations like Chick but not the people.

> proper Bible Doctrine

There is no such thing, it contradicts itself too much. Follow Jesus.
body_html:
On what authority do you claim The Bible isn't God's word? Telling me I have no authority is a nonsensical statement to make. Obviously we are both expressing our opinions and where we place our faith. My faith is in the King James as God's perfect word in English.

The burden of proof is on the accuser. I recall no such incident where God spoke to us and said a book was his word, much less a particular translation of it. In fact, I believe there is an incident in the old testament where God praises the Israelites for rejecting a prophet's message when it wasn't God speaking through him.

Anderson is likely a Jesuit agent. If you aren't aware of controlled opposition, or can't entertain the idea that one person doesn't represent and entire group, then we have little to talk about. I'd like to create a guild on here where Christians founded in proper Bible Doctrine and aware of "conspiracies" can have meaningful conversation and exchanges. You and I won't make any progress.

I only used him as an example because he's the only major KJV-onlyist I can think of. I know of organizations like Chick but not the people.

proper Bible Doctrine

There is no such thing, it contradicts itself too much. Follow Jesus.

post.body_html:
The most jarring example is Shem Tob's copy of the gospel of Matthew in Hebrew. What's bizarre is that it often agrees with Luke over Matthew when using the Q source. Interesting, because often the Lukan version is more primitive and Hebraic than the Matthean version. I don't just mean minor details either. For example, the part where the people ask John what to do in chapter 3 is not extant in canonical Matthew, but it is in Luke...and a shorter version is also found in Hebrew Matthew! My guess is that Q was originally written in Hebrew, and that Shem Tob's text made use of this or padded it out with translations of the parts of Mark that were incorporated. And Matthew and Luke both made use of some sort of Greek translation of this document. More evidence is that the Shem Tob version also has several agreements with the gospel of Thomas over the canonical gospels, which also utilized Q. As well as agreements with long lost manuscripts not available in his time, so these variants could not have been the results of tampering by Jewish scribes (which did happen, as it also did to the canonical version by Roman scribes).

Some of these old manuscripts also appear to be checked against older sources, including Q, and often the original Hebrew version too. Sinaiticus and Bezae in particular have several variants in the synoptic gospels and even Acts which come from older versions than are available to us today, and updates from source documents that were originally erroneously copied. Some manuscripts of the Old Latin and Old Syriac have similar variants.

The gospel of the Hebrews, too, looks like it made use of this document, or an extremely early version of Luke. I cannot say it is Q, as it's definitely edited and harmonized from the existing gospels, but in places it gives a more primitive reading. Such as the beginning: "And it was in the days of Herod king of Judea, during the priesthood of Caiapha, a man named John went..." which is shorter and noticeably more Hebraic than Luke 3:1, and also has an incorrect detail about Herod being king of Judea instead of Galilee (and it's very hard to imagine a redactor editing it to make it shorter and more incorrect).

It may be that the story of the woman caught in adultery is also part of Q, as its style is very Lukan and it appears in a number of early manuscripts in the gospel of Luke instead of John. Perhaps scribes noticed it was not included in any of the canonical gospels and were trying to find a good place to put it before abandoning Q and losing it.
post.title: Shem Tob's Hebrew, Codex Sinaiticus, Codex Bezae, Old Latin and Old Syriac have an interesting link with Q

body:
> Lol so someone saying The KJV Bible is God's word is the accuser? The real accuser is delighted that people are saying that about The Bible.

Stop deflecting. I think you know full well that "the burden of proof is on the accuser" isn't talking about *THE* accuser.

> There are numerous KJV Only Preachers across the country and internet. The accuser made sure to put Anderson in the forefront of your mind though to keep you from it. Social manipulation, you don't want to be "guilty by association".

I am well aware of the differences. Replace Steven Anderson with any other KJV-onlyist and my point stands. They are still making the claim that the KJV is the word of Go with no authority to do so.

> Yours is founded in lies and the authority of men.

In contrast, the idea that the KJV is God's word can come only from the authority of men, as we have zero evidence of God having said such.
body_html:
Lol so someone saying The KJV Bible is God's word is the accuser? The real accuser is delighted that people are saying that about The Bible.

Stop deflecting. I think you know full well that "the burden of proof is on the accuser" isn't talking about THE accuser.

There are numerous KJV Only Preachers across the country and internet. The accuser made sure to put Anderson in the forefront of your mind though to keep you from it. Social manipulation, you don't want to be "guilty by association".

I am well aware of the differences. Replace Steven Anderson with any other KJV-onlyist and my point stands. They are still making the claim that the KJV is the word of Go with no authority to do so.

Yours is founded in lies and the authority of men.

In contrast, the idea that the KJV is God's word can come only from the authority of men, as we have zero evidence of God having said such.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

post.body:
The most jarring example is Shem Tob's copy of the gospel of Matthew in Hebrew. What's bizarre is that it often agrees with *Luke* over Matthew when using the Q source. Interesting, because often the Lukan version is more primitive and Hebraic than the Matthean version. I don't just mean minor details either. For example, the part where the people ask John what to do in chapter 3 is not extant in canonical Matthew, but it *is* in Luke...and a shorter version is also found in Hebrew Matthew! My guess is that Q was originally written in Hebrew, and that Shem Tob's text made use of this or padded it out with translations of the parts of Mark that were incorporated. And Matthew and Luke both made use of some sort of Greek translation of this document. More evidence is that the Shem Tob version also has several agreements with the gospel of Thomas over the canonical gospels, which also utilized Q. As well as agreements with long lost manuscripts not available in his time, so these variants could not have been the results of tampering by Jewish scribes (which did happen, as it also did to the canonical version by Roman scribes).

Some of these old manuscripts also appear to be checked against older sources, including Q, and often the original Hebrew version too. Sinaiticus and Bezae in particular have several variants in the synoptic gospels and even Acts which come from older versions than are available to us today, and updates from source documents that were originally erroneously copied. Some manuscripts of the Old Latin and Old Syriac have similar variants.

The gospel of the Hebrews, too, looks like it made use of this document, or an extremely early version of Luke. I cannot say it *is* Q, as it's definitely edited and harmonized from the existing gospels, but in places it gives a more primitive reading. Such as the beginning: "And it was in the days of Herod king of Judea, during the priesthood of Caiapha, a man named John went..." which is shorter and noticeably more Hebraic than Luke 3:1, and also has an incorrect detail about Herod being king of Judea instead of Galilee (and it's very hard to imagine a redactor editing it to make it shorter and more incorrect).

It may be that the story of the woman caught in adultery is also part of Q, as its style is very Lukan and it appears in a number of early manuscripts in the gospel of Luke instead of John. Perhaps scribes noticed it was not included in any of the canonical gospels and were trying to find a good place to put it before abandoning Q and losing it.
